awd_titl_txt: Field Experiments on Charitable Giving at a Public University
awd_abstract_narration:
This project consists of a field experiment on motivations for charitable giving, conducted in conjunction with the annual fund and capital giving campaign at a major public research university. The collaboration between the researchers and the university has the potential to answer important questions in three main motives for giving: prestige, reciprocity, and social norms. The experiments gauge the effect of prestige (acknowledgment) and giving categories on donations; the importance of gifts and reciprocity (gift exchange) as motives for giving; and the role of social influence and norm compliance on giving. The large sample size allows the researchers to compare the effectiveness of various fundraising techniques, alone and in combination.

Approximately 300,000 former students are randomly assigned to receive different solicitation letters. These letters vary the offer of recognition from the university in response to donations as well as the levels of suggested donations in order to identify whether bunching at the bottom of categories, which has been documented in the existing literature, is due to reference points or a desire for prestige. Additionally, related treatments offer gifts in exchange for donations, as is common for charitable organizations. The mechanisms by which reciprocal gift-giving by the charity affects donative behavior is identified by varying the size of the gifts, the required donation amounts, and the opportunity to opt out of receiving the gift. Giving by donors is examined both in response to the initial solicitation and over the longer term to study persistence in philanthropy.

Charitable giving plays a large role in the United States. The results of this research will provide guidance to practitioners, especially in higher education, on how to raise funds more efficiently, thus increasing both the level of prosocial behavior in general as well as enhancing the ability of organizations to raise funds to promote the provision of higher education. By leveraging an existing campaign, it is possible to accumulate a large new data set that will provide insight into theories of charitable giving that span multiple fields in social science in ways that are not otherwise possible.

por.por_cntn:
Charitable giving plays an important role in modern life, yet many aspects of donation decisions are not well understood. This project examines various aspects of charitable fundraising with an eye towards shedding light on the relationship between charities and their donors. We conducted three field experiments with practitioner partners at Texas A&M University. First, we investigated the nature of gift exchange in charitable giving. Prospective donors were solicited for a donation, given an unconditional gift of varying value, or offered a gift conditional on donating (with the option to receive or not receive that gift). We found that, despite survey evidence to the contrary, donors show a strong preference for receiving gifts from charities, with higher-quality gifts eliciting more donations but not in sufficient quantities to offset their costs. Second, we investigated donors’ preferences to direct their giving. Some prospective donors were offered the choice direct some or all of their donation to the standard Annual Fund or an Academic Fund. We found that donors in the choice treatment gave substantially more, but surprisingly, there was little take-up of the option to direct. Charities are able to raise substantially more merely by offering donors the chance to direct their gift. The final experiment is an extension of the second one on a much larger scale and scope. High-capacity donors are offered different sets of priorities, including the administrative costs of the charity, to which they can direct their giving.

Taken together, the results from these experiments broaden our understanding of the mechanisms by which individuals choose the targets of their philanthropy, not to mention the amounts they are willing to give. Moreover, given the enormous expenditure on fundraising activities (the ten largest charities in the United States alone spent over $1.2 billion on fundraising in 2012), raising funds more efficiently will enable more philanthropic activities. This research is particularly relevant to public postsecondary institutions that are seeking alternative funding methods as government funding is reduced. These results have the potential to increase both the level of prosocial behavior in general as well as the provision of higher education.
